attributes.title: Internet Usage and Class Performance
attributes.description: Our group is interested in duplicating and expanding on the study "Logged in and Zoned Out: How Laptop Internet Use Relates to Classroom Learning." We want to learn about how cell phone and computer use with the internet and different apps can affect classroom performance.

q2.value: Bria Turner, Lexi Reese, Katelyn Brooks, Jordan Lucas, Samantha Harris

q3.value: We are interested in duplicated but expanding on the study "Logged in and Zoned Out: How Laptop Internet Use Relates to Classroom Learning". There is already research supporting how classroom performance decreases with internet and computer usage. We do want to replicate this but we want to include this with cell phones. Our group will measure how both cell phone and computer usage will impact final grade performance.

q4.value: As the more time students spend using their computer and/or phone for nonacademic reasons the lower your cumulative final grade will be. With increase interest in the class material decreases the amount of time spent on electronics.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It is going to be an observational study. We will have the participants log into a server on the computer and cell phone to collect data on what they are using.

q9.value: There will be no randomization because we are just observing there data and seeing what their performance is in the class.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 84 students enrolled in an introductory psychology class in fall 2014 were chosen to participate in the study. In order to participate in the study, they had to check into the proxy server during more than half of the 15 sessions and logged in an average of 12.7 times. They were offered course credit of they were to participate.

q13.value: 84 students will be analyzed in the study. 56.5% were freshmen, 33.9% were sophomores, 5.7% were juniors, and 4.0% were seniors.

q14.value: We used a proxy server that monitored student’s online activity during class. It measured time, frequency, and browsing history of participants internet usage. Also, we assessed whether intelligence, motivation, and interest in course material

q15.value: Students will log into a proxy server on their laptop before every class to document their internet usage.

question.value: n/a
Actual internet use,

We will use different ANOVA measures to analyze the results of this experiment. There's also a Pearson Correlation measure that we will use as well. The following variables will be of interest to us in this experiment. Average duration online, an average number of requests, self-reported use, classroom performance, and intelligence.

q20.value: We are not transforming, centering or recoding the data in the experiment.

q21.value: For non-academic use, the p-value is 0.001. For Correlations Among Cumulative Final-Exam Score, Actual Internet Use, Composite ACT Score, Motivation to Do Well in Class, and Interest in Class the p-value is 0.05. The Correlations Between Cumulative Final-Exam Score and Actual Nonacademic Internet Use for the Seven Site Categories, the p-value was both 0.10 and 0.05.

q22.value: We will include all of the data points. The study showed no data being excluded, and since we are replicating the study, the data won't be any different.

q23.value: Missing and incomplete data will be noted in the study.

q24.value: We don't plan on exploring any data, this is just a replication study.

attributes.title: Establishing the social licence to introduce tracking technologies to address COVID-19
attributes.description:
The novel coronavirus or COVID-19 was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization on March 11th, 2020 (World Health Organization, 2020). The COVID-19 virus transmits early in its life cycle relative to other coronaviruses, (e.g., SARS), during which time many individuals present as asymptomatic (Zhou et al., 2020). The moderate to high transmissibility of this virus has required governments to consider moderate to extreme measures in order to prevent further transmissions. Indeed, the nature of the COVID-19 pandemic may require governments to use big data technologies to help contain its spread (Bonsall, Parker, & Fraser, 2020). 

Countries that have managed to “flatten the curve” - the process of slowing the exponential transmission rate of the virus, for example, Singapore and Taiwan - have employed collocation tracking through mobile Wi-Fi, GPS, and Bluetooth as a strategy to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 (Wang et al., 2020). Through collocation tracking, government agencies may observe who you have been in contact with and when this contact occurred, allowing for the rapid implementation of appropriate measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19. 

The effectiveness of collocation tracking relies on the willingness of the population to support such measures, implying that government policy-making should be informed by the likelihood of public compliance. Gaining the social license - broad community acceptance beyond formal legal requirements - for collocation tracking requires the perceived public health benefits to outweigh concerns of personal privacy, security, and any potential risk of harm. 

In the current study, we propose a longitudinal cross-cultural study mapping the evolution of people’s attitudes towards government tracking during the COVID-19 crisis. We aim to understand (1) the factors that influence the social license around governmental use of location tracking data in an emergency, (2) how this may change over time, and (3) how it may differ across cultures. We will present participants with one of two scenarios describing mild or severe government tracking methods that may reduce the spread of COVID-19, and then question participants’ attitudes towards the proposed methods.

q1.value: Simon Dennis, Paul Garrett, Joshua White, Yoshihisa Kashima, Amy Perfors, Daniel R. Little, Stephan Lewandowsky, Nic Geard, Lewis Mitchell, Martin Tomko, Philipp Lorenz-Spreen

q2.value: We hypothesize that participants’ attitude towards government collocation tracking will become more negative as the severity of the tracking methods increase. We expect these attitudes to become more positive as the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic worsen. We expect these attitudes will vary across cultures with more collective cultures (like Japan) being more willing to accept tracking than more individualistic cultures (like Australia) during similar phases of the pandemic.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (Government mobile tracking vignette) and 2 levels (mild, and severe).

q7.value: A representative sample of participants will be randomized between two possible scenarios: Government tracking mild and Government tracking severe.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A representative sample of 1000 Australian participants aged 18 or older will be recruited through the market research platform ‘Dynata’ once every week for four weeks. Participants will be asked to complete a Qualtrics survey on attitudes towards Government tracking and will be incentivized according to their agreement with Dynata. Incentives may take the form of gift cards, points programs, charitable contributions, and partner products or services. A similar procedure will be performed in Japan, however, a similar market research platform is yet to be identified.

q11.value: For each country, we plan to sample 1000 participants each week for four weeks. These will be representative samples and will be evenly split between mild and severe Government tracking scenarios.

q12.value: This sample size was primarily constrained by time and money, given the pressing nature of the COVID-19 outbreak.

question.value: The severity of government tracking will be manipulated between two scenarios. Participants will view only one scenario and answer questions about their attitudes towards the described tracking methods. Tracking method descriptions primarily differ by i) whether participation was optional or mandatory, and whether the government would use tracking data to ii) inform individuals when they may have been exposed to COVID-19, or to enforce individualized lockdown laws through fines and arrests. The two scenarios are attached.

In addition to collecting basic demographic information, we will assess the participant’s attitudes towards government tracking methods and their opinions on societal issues. Survey items are located in the attached document. We will also collect location information (GPS coordinates and IP addresses) to facilitate epidemiological modeling associated with this project. Survey questions are attached.

Measures from each question will be combined across participants through indices of central tendency: the mean, median, and standard deviation. 

Response frequency and percentages will be used to characterize questions of gender, education, job loss, primary sources of COVID-19 information, and whether the participant or someone they know has tested positive to COVID-19. Mean and standard deviations will be used to characterize age. 

A measure of world view will be made by averaging across measures of social opinion: “An economic system based on free markets unrestrained by government interference automatically works best to meet human needs”, “The free market system may be efficient for resource allocation but it is limited in its capacity to promote social justice”, and “The government should interfere with the lives of citizens as little as possible”. See Analysis Plan for further details.

H1. To assess if participants’ attitudes towards government collocation tracking will become more negative as the severity of the tracking methods increase, we will assess differences in acceptability of tracking between the mild and severe scenarios with a Bayesian t-test. 

We will also use a Bayesian t-test to assess how the acceptability of Government tracking changes within scenarios directly after reading the scenario and directly after answering questions about the scenario.

H2. To assess how and why Government tracking acceptability changes over time, we will use two Bayesian logit models. The first model will assess the acceptability of Government tracking directly after reading the scenario. Model inputs will include demographics and responses-made prior to reading the scenario (see Questions document). The model prior will be a Laplacian distribution centered on zero (biased to no effect) and our results will focus upon those inputs that overcome this bias to produce positive beta weights. The second model is the same as the first, however, it will assess the acceptability of Government tracking after answering questions about the scenario. All responses will act as inputs for the second model. 

We will assess how tracking acceptability (pre- and post-questioning), perceived severity, concern for self, concern for others, and job loss change over the four-week interval. We will plot these variables over time with 95% confidence intervals and report changes in trend. 

We will further relate changes in participant responses and the results of the above models to reported changes in the number of total positive COVID-19 cases, the number of total COVID-19 deaths, and their respective rates of change. These numbers may be found through the 	
European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.

H3. To assess how acceptability changes across cultures we will examine differences between the above trends and model fits.

q18.value: Likert responses will be transformed through group-mean centering. The free-market world view question “The government should interfere with the lives of citizens as little as possible” will be reverse scored.

q19.value: We will report Bayesian inference criteria using beta weights and, where necessary, report Bayes factors following the general classification scheme of Jeffreys (1961) and frequentist statistics using an alpha of p < .05. See Analysis Plan for details.

q20.value: Participant data will be excluded if they fail a basic attention check placed within the survey or if they complete less than 80% of the survey.

q22.value: We will incorporate location and IP server information in addition to descriptive statistics of the previously mentioned measures to inform unspecified epidemiological, agent-based and geospatial models of disease spread.

q23.value:

Jeffreys, H. (1961). Theory of probability, 3rd ed Oxford: Oxford university press.

The world health organization (WHO). WHO announces COVID-19 outbreak a pandemic. Retrieved from http://www.euro.who.int/en/health-topics/health-emergencies/coronavirus-covid-19/news/news/2020/3/who-announces-covid-19-outbreak-a-pandemic. 

Wang, C. J., Ng, C. Y., & Brook, R. H. (2020). Response to COVID-19 in Taiwan: big data analytics, new technology, and proactive testing. JAMA.

Zhou, T., Liu, Q., Yang, Z., Liao, J., Yang, K., Bai, W., ... & Zhang, W. (2020). Preliminary prediction of the basic reproduction number of the Wuhan novel coronavirus 2019‐nCoV. Journal of Evidence‐Based Medicine.

subjects.text: Public Affairs, Public Policy and Public Administration
Public Affairs, Public Policy and Public Administration

q2.value: David Bryce Yaden, Meghan Bathgate, Jennifer Claydon, Belinda Platt, Laurie Santos

q3.value:
This study will use a between-groups experimental design to compare how different Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) affect student well-being.  Our more specific goal is to test whether MOOCs that teach learners about the science of happiness can improve student well-being above and beyond that of a typical MOOC. Our experimental treatment group consists of students who have signed up to complete a Science of Well-being Course and our control condition consists of students who have completed an Introduction to Psychology Course (which does not cover the science of well-being). 

As a pilot project, we initially downloaded and analyzed one time-span worth of data from these two courses. This pre-registration document pertains to an additional time-span of data that has since become available for download but has not yet been analyzed. The main purpose of this document is to state our hypotheses and to have a record of our research questions, sampling plan, measures, and initial plan for key analyses, prior to data analysis.

q4.value:
Measures:
Well-Being Measure – The PERMA Profiler is a well-being measure that taps five dimensions of well-being: Positive Emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment. An overall score can be computed from these dimensions. There are also ‘filler’ questions that will not be analyzed.
-	Butler, J., & Kern, M. L. (2016). The PERMA-Profiler: A brief multidimensional measure of flourishing. International Journal of Wellbeing, 6(3).

Hypotheses:
Our hypotheses for this study:
-	Hypothesis 1: Students will not differ at baseline between the Science of Well-being Course and the Introduction to Psychology Course on their Overall PERMA scores.
-	Hypothesis 2: Students will differ at follow-up between the Science of Well-being Course and the Introduction to Psychology Course on their Overall PERMA scores.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Design Plan
Between-groups experimental design. Participants self-selected into either course and thus were not randomly assigned to condition. Nevertheless, we will compare baseline well-being for both groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value:
Sampling Plan:
Registration prior to analysis of data: As of the date of submission of this research plan for preregistration, the data have been collected but they have not been explored or analyzed.

question.value:
Data collection procedures: Data have been gathered from students who took a MOOC about either well-being research in psychology or an introduction to psychology. Only data from consenting individuals will be analyzed. The Institutional Review Board at Yale University approved this study.

Data exclusion: We will exclude participants who do not meet several criteria. First, participants must have only completed the well-being assessments once at the start and end of the MOOC course. Second, participants must have completed the entire assessment survey. Third, participants who reported completing the 10-week course in under 2 weeks were excluded, as it would not be possible to complete the assignments properly.

q13.value: The first study sample size was ~1,200 and we expect that the second timespan will have about the same size sample.

q14.value: Limited by students enrolling and finishing the course.

question.value:
Measures:
Well-Being Measure – The PERMA Profiler is a well-being measure that taps five dimensions of well-being: Positive Emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment. An overall score can be computed from these dimensions. There are also ‘filler’ questions that will not be analyzed.
-	Butler, J., & Kern, M. L. (2016). The PERMA-Profiler: A brief multidimensional measure of flourishing. International Journal of Wellbeing, 6(3).

Analysis Plan
Independent sample t-tests will be conducted to compare baseline Overall PERMA scores to test if there is a difference between groups. Independent sample t-tests will then be conducted to compare follow-up scores between groups, and we predict that there will be a difference between groups, where the Science of Well-being course scores are higher.

The other five dimensions of PERMA will be reported in both courses at both baseline and follow-up. Additionally, the particular interventions that participants chose to engage in will be reported as they relate to follow-up well-being in the Science of Well-Being course. We have no hypotheses related to these exploratory analyses. We may conduct additional exploratory analysis and will report these additional analyses as exploratory.

attributes.title: Book Reviews and the Consolidation of Genre
attributes.description: Several interconnected experiments that use book reviews of fiction to trace the rise and fall of genre concepts.

summary.value:
second registration
===================

These experiments continue to explore the questions we were posing in our earlier inquiry. Especially this question:

`Do genre categories generally become more crisply defined or more closely knit as we move from the late 19c, through the 20c, to the present?`

Both of the experiments below are based on the intuition that the coherence and "tightness" of generic clustering in different periods can be assessed by measuring the difference between the average (random) distances between books and the distances measured between pairs of books that share a genre. The greater the difference, the more strongly books appear to be sorted by genre. This measure is loosely analogous to one called [silhouette value](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silhouette_(clustering)). The difference is that the silhouette strategy is designed for complete partitioning of a single dataset, and we need to evaluate a window that slides down a timeline.

While the distances between word vectors derived from book texts don't have obvious inherent significance in themselves, we know from our previous experiments that these distances do in practice correlate with the accuracy of predictive models--and also with predictive models of *reviews*. There is also [some previous research](https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/W18-4507/) that directly connects all of these measures to human perceptions of generic similarity and difference. So we do have some reason to treat these distances as a proxy for human judgment, although they are to be sure an imperfect proxy.

first experiment: genres assigned by librarians
------------------------------------------------

First, we plan to test the coherence of the genre categories defined by the librarians who assigned Library of Congress subject and genre headings recorded in HathiTrust metadata, from 1860 to 2010.

We grouped LoC genre and subject headings into nineteen categories. For instance "Mystery fiction" and "Detective and mystery stories, American" belong to the same category. See `genre_groups_for_20c_exp.tsv` for these categories.

Next we will measure in-genre distance by selecting pairs of books in the same category, and measuring the cosine distance between their texts, using a vector of relative frequencies constructed with the 2500 most common words in the entire corpus. We will use tf-idf scaling to adjust the vectors--reflecting our intuition that relatively uncommon words are more important in discriminating genres than their sheer frequency might suggest.

(We could alternately do no adjustment, or scale all the words to have equal weight--i.e., compare z scores of the frequencies. We have tried both of these things in a previous experiment, and it didn't make a great deal of difference. A pattern durable enough to be of real significance for us should probably hold true across most methodological details of this kind.)

We will only compare books published within ten years of each other, according to our metadata. Call these books Ax and Ay (genre A, in years x and y).

As a control for each in-genre comparison, we will compare the first book in genre A (Ax) to a randomly selected book in year y (Ry), and the second book (Ay) to a randomly selected book in year x (Rx). We will try two different forms of "random selection": one is to randomly select a book from the list of books assigned to other genres. Another is to randomly select a book from a subset of books that were genuinely plucked randomly from HathiTrust (including books without any genre categorization). We consider the second more reliable, but the difference between these measurements might also be of interest.

So the overall outgenre - ingenre difference is

    ((Ax to Ry + Rx to Ay) / 2) - (Ax to Ay)

We'll date each measurement at the midpoint of years x and y.

**Hypothesis to test:**

We expect that there is some year Y in the second half of the twentieth century, such that average generic closeness (outgenre_distance - ingenre_distance) increases from 1860 to that year, and decreases thereafter, where "increases" and "decreases" describe a correlation with time. We expect both correlations to be significant at p < .05, if we compare the differences for individual pairs of books to the midpoint dates for those pairs.

second experiment: genre categories derived from a topic model of Kirkus Reviews
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The chief objection to our first experiment will be that we're using genre categories assigned retrospectively, mostly by late-twentieth-century librarians. It is possible that genres would seem more cohesive toward the end of the timeline because the genre categories were created in that period, and are simply a better fit for books at the end of the timeline.

There are several ways to address this concern; by summer, we'll be able to use explicit genre categories derived from the index of the *Book Review Digest.* But in the meantime we can use book reviews as a source of genre-like categories that were assigned by readers closer to the date of a book's publication.

After optimizing the number of topics, we produced an 80-topic model of Kirkus book reviews from 1930 to 2010. We manually inspected the model to identify 23 topics that seemed genre-*like*. (See `genre_80_mallet_categories_for_20c_exp.csv.`) We didn't expect a 1:1 mapping between topics and library genre labels, but we did try to exclude topics that were, for instance, organized around different types of evaluative language rather than different *kinds* of books.

We will evaluate these 23 topics in the same way as we evaluated the 19 library-assigned categories above. In other words, we'll select pairs of books in the same review topic, measure the Ax-Ay distance, and then compare it to the average of Ax-Ry and Rx-Ay. We'll plot the differences between in-topic and out-topic distance across a timeline.

**Hypotheses to test:**

The measurement we're making here is not purely a measurement of the cohesiveness of known groups. It is better understood as a measure of the *alignment* between review-descriptions and book-texts. If the categories inferred from reviews are also strongly marked in the books, there will be a big difference between in-topic and out-topic distance. If those categories are not strongly aligned, the difference may be smaller.

We tentatively interpret the strength of alignment as an indication that genre categories are widely recognized and shared between writers and readers.

So the first hypothesis we offer is that the average out-topic/in-topic difference, aggregated by year, will correlate with the yearly measurement in our first experiment. If this is true, we'll conclude that the retrospective character of categories in our first experiment was not the only source of the observed pattern. We're really measuring how strongly books were sorted into reception categories at the time of publication.

We also, secondarily, hypothesize that the out-topic/in-topic difference will in general be greatest when a topic is most prevalent in the model. In other words, when a "science fiction" topic is just beginning to emerge in reception, books may not yet be very clearly sorted into that category. But when it reaches its peak (measured as the proportion of words in year Y assigned to the topic), we would expect it to be a more prominent category in reception.

Since we're interested in a topic's peak relative to its own distribution, not its absolute size, we will measure a topic's relative "prevalence" in this experiment as `words in topic T, year Y / all words in topic T`.

To formalize this as a hypothesis we can test: if we measure out-topic/in-topic difference for topic X in year Y, and the relative prevalence of the topic in year Y, and aggregate those measurements across all years and topics, we expect a very small but significant (p < .05) correlation between the two variables.

It would also be interesting if this correlation were improved by sliding the two sets of measurements relative to each other on the timeline. In other words, do topics tend to reach peak prevalence *before*, or *after*, books are most clearly sorted into the topic? We'll pose that question for now in an exploratory way; it might help us frame a hypothesis about the causal relations between writing and reception.

second registration
===================

attributes.title: Prospective Effort on a Naming Task

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Retrospective Effort on a Naming Task: Silent Reading Replication

sample.value: A sample size of 720 was determined by previous research (please see https://osf.io/qvk2p).

analyses.value:
A single factor between-ss ANOVA with stimulus type (i.e., UW-UF, UW-RF, RW-UF, RW-RF) as the factor and effort rating as the DV to determine if there are differences in effort during separate evaluation. In the event of a significant F-test, pairwise t-tests will be conducted.

A single factor repeated measures ANOVA with stimulus type as the factor and effort rating as the DV to determine if there are differences in effort during joint evaluation. In the event of a significant F-test, pairwise t-tests will be conducted. 

An Erlebacher's analysis (Erlebacher, 1977) will be conducted to determine whether there is a significant interaction of design type (repeated measures; between-ss) and the stimulus type. As Erlebacher's analysis requires equal cell sizes, participants may have to be excluded from some of Conditions 1-4. In these cases, those with the latest time stamps associated with their Qualtrics data will be removed. 

To further examine the relation between design and stimulus type, the following planned analyses will be conducted:
0. [[NEW]] A 2(design type) x 3(stimulus type: UW-RF, RW-UF, RW-RF) Erlebacher's analysis
1. A 2(design type) x 2(stimulus type: RW-UF vs. RW-RF) Erlebacher's analysis
2. A 2(design type) x 2(stimulus type: UW-RF vs. RW-UF) Erlebacher's analysis
3. A 2(design type) x 2(stimulus type: UW-UF and frame vs. all rotated stimulus types) Erlebacher's analysis. "all rotated stimulus types" for the between-ss data will be computed by pseudo-randomly (i.e., balanced across the other three conditions) dropping 2 of every 3 effort judgments. 

Secondary analysis:

A 3 (stimulus type: UW-RF, RW-UF, RW-RF) x 2 (direction of rotation: counterclockwise vs. clockwise) two-way ANOVA will be conducted for each of the between-ss (conditions 1-4 above) and within-ss (condition 5 above) data to test the interaction between stimulus type and direction of rotation. In the event of a significant F-test, pairwise t-tests will be conducted. 

Four one-way between-ss ANOVAs will be conducted to test whether the counterbalances affected judgments of effort in conditions 1, 2, 3 and 4 separately. In the event of a significant F-test, pairwise comparisons will be conducted.

outliers.value:
Exclusions of data: 
--An attention check question is part of the study. We will include data from a participant if they correctly answer this question. 
--If a participant decides to withdraw after consenting to participate, they will click through the survey. Responses will be left partly or completely blank. In these cases participants' data will not be included.

conditions.value:
There are five conditions to which participants will be randomly assigned. Four of these conditions (1-4) involve a stimulus type consisting of a 25-word array that contains rotated words that are upright or rotated within a frame that itself is either upright or rotated. These conditions are below:
1. UW-UF: One array with upright words and upright frame with one effort scale
2. UW-RF: One array with upright words and rotated frame with one effort scale
3. RW-UF: One array with rotated words and upright frame with one effort scale
4. RW-RF: One array with rotated words and rotated frame with one effort scale
5. Condition 5 is the joint presentation of all arrays from condition 1-4 (i.e., UW-UF, UW-RF, RW-UF, and RW-RF shown on the same page), with prospective effort for each array judged on four separate scales. 

Additionally, there were four unique sets of 25 words that were counterbalanced across the various stimulus types.

hypothesis.value: Does presentation (joint vs. separate) of multi-element arrays influence retrospective judgments of effort?

attributes.title: Evaluating the Effect of Stereotype Threat on Law Graduates' Bar Exam Performance
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

dataCollectionDates.value: Data collection started in March 2019.  Data collection is still underway—we have yet to combine bar passage results with data on stereotype threat to analyze these relationships.  It may take until March 2019 to complete the analyses proposed.

question2a.value: [Predictor] Stereotype Threat on Bar Exam (Continuous Variable)

question2b.value:
List dependent variables, or variables in a correlational design

[DV1] Bar Passage (Dichotomous Variable)

[DV2] Total Bar Score (Continuous Variable), Transformed by State Bar

[DV3] MBE Score (Continuous Variable), Transformed by State Bar

[DV4] Essay Score (Continuous Variable), Transformed by State Bar

question3b.value:
Third variables acting as covariates or moderators.

[Moderator 1] Racial Disadvantage 

[Moderator 2] SES

[Moderator 3] Racial Disadvantage or Low SES vs. Non-Racial Disadvantage and Not Low-SES

[CoV1] Prior Performance:  LSAT Score and/or Law School Grades
* We may use a covariate to control for prior performance. We may also explore the interaction between racial group membership and prior performance on the relationship between stereotype threat and bar performance.

question10b.value:
In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we delivered a program online to applicants who sat for California’s July 2019 Bar exam. 

Beginning in March, test takers registering for the California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in. In so doing, they consented to participate in the program and permitted analysis of their Bar exam results.  At this recruitment stage, we gathered pre-intervention measures, including racial group membership, LSAT and their law school GPA, and matched the law school of each bar exam taker to the U.S. News & World Report Rankings.  At the time of recruitment, we measured whether participants experienced stereotype threat about preparing for the bar exam. 

The State Bar will provide bar exam results to the research team in January 2020, and the research team will then match these bar results to the predictor variables at the participant level for conducting this proposed analysis.  

[Predictor] Stereotype Threat: 
Q.  How often do you think that other people would be surprised if you, or people like you, passed the bar exam? 1-Never, 7-Extremely often

[Moderator 1] Racial Disadvantage:
We measuring racial disadvantage in 4 different ways, which vary, for example whether Asian Americans are considered members of the racial disadvantage or advantage group, and how participants who selected more than one racial disadvantage group are included.  

[Moderator 2] SES:
Think of this ladder as representing where people stand in the United States.  At the top of the ladder are the people who are the best off--those who have the most money, the most education, and the most respected jobs.  At the bottom are the people who are the worst off--those who have the least money, the least education, and the least respected jobs or no job.  The higher up you are on this ladder, the closer you are to the people at the very top; the lower you are, the closer you are to the people at the very bottom.  1 - 10. 

We may also measure SES based upon the highest level of education mother (or first guardian/caregiver) or father (second guardian/caregiver) has obtained. 


[Moderator 3] Racial Disadvantage or Low SES vs. Non-Racial Disadvantage and Not Low-SES
* This analysis essentially combines the data in the above two categories and forms a disadvantage group that includes both racial and ethnic disadvantage and SES disadvantage and compares this with those who are in neither of these disadvantaged groups.

question4b.value: All test takers registering for the July 2019 California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in the program.

question5b.value:
In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we delivered a program online to applicants who sat for California’s July 2019 Bar exam. 

Beginning in March, test takers registering for the California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in. In so doing, they consented to participate in the program and permitted analysis of their Bar exam results.  At this recruitment stage, we gathered measures, including LSAT and their law school GPA, racial group membership, SES, and measures of stereotype threat.  

Each bar applicant then took the bar exam in July 2019.  

The State Bar will provide bar exam results to the research team in January 2020, and the research team will then match these bar results to the predictor variables at the participant level for conducting this proposed analysis.

question6b.value: Our planned sample size includes all bar exam takers who opted into the program and meet the above pre- and post-selection rules.

question7b.value: We stopped data collection at the point at which participants were no longer able to register for the July 2019 California bar exam.

question8b.value:
a) U.S. Law Students:  For purposes of this pre-registration, we are seeking to confirm the hypothesis that among U.S. law students stereotype threat on the bar exam is negatively related to bar performance.  We are excluding foreign law students, foreign law schools, repeat-test takers, and out-of-state attorneys in this analysis.  

b) Not Completing the Exam:  We are not including bar applicants for whom we do not receive bar score data as they did not sit for the exam.  

c) Bar Score Outliers:  We are not including bar applicants who scored +/- 3 SD from the mean outcome on the July 2019 bar exam when examining bar scores as a continuous measure.

question9b.value: We have no study termination rules.

question7c.value: Deletion Type: Listwise deletion will be used, for example, when we do not have LSAT or LGPA.

question1a.value: [H1] Relationship Between Stereotype Threat and Bar Performance:  We expect that measured stereotype threat is negatively related to bar exam performance, such that U.S. law students who experience greater levels of stereotype threat on the bar exam will perform less well on the bar exam.

question2a.value: [H2] Stereotype Threat Moderated by Group Membership Between Stereotype Threat and Bar Performance:  We will explore moderation by examining whether this negative relationship is stronger for members of racially disadvantaged groups compared to those in advantaged groups.

question5a.value:
We propose that stereotype threat plays an under-recognized role as a potential factor that shapes performance on the bar exam. 

In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we designed a program for the July 2018 California bar exam. The program was offered to recent U.S. law school graduates and to applicants repeating the exam.  When collecting data as part of this program, our research team observed that stereotype threat was negatively correlated with and negatively predictive of performance on the bar exam. 

We replicated the program on California’s July 2019 Bar exam and prior to analyzing this data, we now pre-register a direct replication of this analysis (that is, whether stereotype threat is again negatively correlated with bar performance among U.S. law student taking the bar exam).  

[RQ1] Is measured stereotype threat experienced about the bar exam negatively associated with performance on the bar exam?  

[RQ2] If so, does the negative relationship between stereotype threat and performance on the bar exam vary based upon social group membership.

[RQ1] Is measured stereotype threat experienced about the bar exam negatively associated with performance on the bar exam?  

[RQ2] If so, does the negative relationship between stereotype threat and performance on the bar exam vary based upon social group membership.

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we delivered a program online to applicants who sat for California’s July 2019 Bar exam. 

Beginning in March, test takers registering for the California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in. In so doing, they consented to participate in the program and permitted analysis of their Bar exam results.  At this recruitment stage, we gathered pre-intervention measures, including racial group membership, LSAT and their law school GPA, and matched the law school of each bar exam taker to the U.S. News & World Report Rankings.  At the time of recruitment, we measured whether participants experienced stereotype threat about preparing for the bar exam. 

The State Bar will provide bar exam results to the research team in January 2020, and the research team will then match these bar results to the predictor variables at the participant level for conducting this proposed analysis.  

[Predictor] Stereotype Threat: 
Q.  How often do you think that other people would be surprised if you, or people like you, passed the bar exam? 1-Never, 7-Extremely often

[Moderator 1] Racial Disadvantage:
We measuring racial disadvantage in 4 different ways, which vary, for example whether Asian Americans are considered members of the racial disadvantage or advantage group, and how participants who selected more than one racial disadvantage group are included.  

[Moderator 2] SES:
Think of this ladder as representing where people stand in the United States.  At the top of the ladder are the people who are the best off--those who have the most money, the most education, and the most respected jobs.  At the bottom are the people who are the worst off--those who have the least money, the least education, and the least respected jobs or no job.  The higher up you are on this ladder, the closer you are to the people at the very top; the lower you are, the closer you are to the people at the very bottom.  1 - 10. 

We may also measure SES based upon the highest level of education mother (or first guardian/caregiver) or father (second guardian/caregiver) has obtained. 


[Moderator 3] Racial Disadvantage or Low SES vs. Non-Racial Disadvantage and Not Low-SES
* This analysis essentially combines the data in the above two categories and forms a disadvantage group that includes both racial and ethnic disadvantage and SES disadvantage and compares this with those who are in neither of these disadvantaged groups.

Test: OLS Regression

Predictor: Stereotype Threat

DV: Bar Passage or Bar Performance

Covariate*: LSAT, or Law School GPA, or standardized composites of these variables. 

All of the above analyses will be conducted with bar applicants who registered for the bar exam in the timely filing window, and the late filing window, and then combining those who timely filed and late filed for the bar exam.

* We are looking at the three covariates because we seek to understand the effect of stereotype threat above and beyond past performance and ability. Past research suggests that stereotype threat may directly predict bar performance without covariates, but that including covariates in the model may control for past performance as well.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: All test takers registering for the July 2019 California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in the program.

In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we delivered a program online to applicants who sat for California’s July 2019 Bar exam. 

Beginning in March, test takers registering for the California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in. In so doing, they consented to participate in the program and permitted analysis of their Bar exam results.  At this recruitment stage, we gathered measures, including LSAT and their law school GPA, racial group membership, SES, and measures of stereotype threat.  

Each bar applicant then took the bar exam in July 2019.  

The State Bar will provide bar exam results to the research team in January 2020, and the research team will then match these bar results to the predictor variables at the participant level for conducting this proposed analysis.
Our planned sample size includes all bar exam takers who opted into the program and meet the above pre- and post-selection rules.
We stopped data collection at the point at which participants were no longer able to register for the July 2019 California bar exam.

registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a) U.S. Law Students:  For purposes of this pre-registration, we are seeking to confirm the hypothesis that among U.S. law students stereotype threat on the bar exam is negatively related to bar performance.  We are excluding foreign law students, foreign law schools, repeat-test takers, and out-of-state attorneys in this analysis.  

b) Not Completing the Exam:  We are not including bar applicants for whom we do not receive bar score data as they did not sit for the exam.  

c) Bar Score Outliers:  We are not including bar applicants who scored +/- 3 SD from the mean outcome on the July 2019 bar exam when examining bar scores as a continuous measure.

attributes.title: The belief in the unstructured interview
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to seek why people persist in the belief that unstructured interviews have some validity in the selection process and why these misapprehensions are harmful to applicants.

q1.value: The belief in the unstructured interview.

q2.value: Chris Edwards , Robyn Giraud, Madeline Saucier, Kaity Elwin , Horatio Traylor

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to seek why people persist in the belief that unstructured interviews have some validity in the selection process and why these misapprehensions are harmful to applicants.

q4.value: While Empirical data has show that structured interviews are often better and more reliable, there are still beliefs in favor for unstructured interviews. We believe that the theoretical justification of possibly missing out hidden attributes in the interviewee for a unstructured interview will unintentionally negatively influence the decisions and responses from the applicants, leading to a less reliable method.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
There will be 3 levels of the study. A between subjects design will be used for all levels. For the first level, participants (who are the interviewers) are randomly assigned to 1 of 3 different styles of interviews. 1. Accurate condition 2. Random Condition 
3. Natural condition. Participants were also randomly assigned to interviewees. The goal is to accurately predict the interviewee's current GPA.  Each participant will interview two different people. One with biographical information presented only (control) and one with biographical information with prior GPA and an interview. The second level will use a different sample of students and they are tasked to watch a pre-recorded interview of other an student's interview. The questions are preselected for the interviewer to eliminate as much sense bias as possible. For each interviewee one accurate and one random interview are to be recorded. Participants are randomly assigned to watch one of the interviews and later asked through a questionnaire if they agreed or disagreed wether the interview was helpful. A Likert scale will be used 1=strongly disagree and 5= strongly agree. Finally participants were informed that the interview was drawn from a pool of half random interviews. For the third level, participants will be asked to rank in order which interview (including the no interview option) they think is the most helpful in determining validity.

q9.value: Simple random sampling will be used to determine which participant is assigned to which interviewee and type of interview based  by randomly drawing from a pool .  For the participants, convenience sampling will be used. EX: college undergraduates.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Carnegie Mellon University. Participants will be recruited through campus & will be paid for particpating. There are 5 interviewees that  vary in age from 18-22; they represent multiple races, majors and class standings. Participants cumulative GPA's and semesters GPA's are listed.

q13.value: The target sample size is 306 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 350; based on the assumption that not every participant will complete the task.

question.value: We manipulated the percentage of guesses by interview type. The 3 levels of this variable is: accurate, random and natural guess types.
The single outcome variable will be the predicted accuracy for each participants. We will measure this by using a questionaire (likert scale: 1= disagree, 4= agree)

In study 1 for our statistical models, we will be running a correlation (with actual outcomes) using Hotelling's method for dependent r with Williams correction to assess the validity of GPA predictions following interviews (r), as well as the validity of using the prior GPA attained alone. We will also be testing the validity of three conditions: random, natural, and accurate. In study 2, GPAs will be correlated the same way as study 1.
 
Furthermore: we plan to run a complete regression analysis with 7 different predictors across two separate studies. The predictors are as follows: Actual GPA, Access to interview, Actual GPA (x) interview, Q1, Q2, Actual GPA x Q1, Actual GPA x Q2. 

The two studies will be correlated together to determine if there is a dilution to determine that prior GPA alone predicts significantly better than our participants do with interviews. Study 2 will also use a frequency based statistical model to indicate the accurate/random guess by interview type.

Study 3 uses a frequency based statistical model to determine how students rank the different interview methods based on the previous studies.

q20.value: We plan on recoding the data in our regression analysis to include numbers corresponding to each study. Following as Study 1: (1) Study 2: (2) All: (3) Study 1 (4) Study 2 (5) All (6) .

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the correlation suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis was correct. We will also include the p<0.001 criteria for establishing another level of significance. The two criteria will be denoted by *p<.05 and **p<.001 respectively.

q22.value: We will verify that subjects are accurately indicating their responses on each Likert question.  With the limited amount of responses, there should not be any outliers, unless a participant skips questions, in which case their responses will not be included (see below).

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the Likert scale questions, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that even though participants will not have the ability to direct their own questions in study 2, they may still form an impression about the interviewee's due to sense-making. However, we expect that it will be less than if the subject were able to form their own opinions based on confirming their assumptions through asking questions. Therefore, we will look for if the subjective impressions of the interviewee will be changed through random responding. We will do this by looking for if the subject feels that they are able to infer a lot about the interviewee through watching the interview.

q25.value:
This will be a replication study.

question10b.value:
The program was designed as a randomized control trial (RCT).  Random assignment of Bar takers ensures the random dispersal of student traits (e.g., GPA, demographic details) between conditions. Moreover, a statistical package was applied that ensured that average prior performance scores (i.e., LSAT and law school GPA) were equal within the treatment and control condition. Every participating bar taker was then randomly assigned into either (1) the active control condition, where they learned bar exam study strategies; or (2) the treatment condition, where they received the productive mindset intervention as well as bar exam study strategies. This left the intervention treatment as the only systematic difference between the conditions.  

Those who opted-in received a link to the program in May. The program incorporated an introductory film, audio and written stories from prior test takers, and a module in which participants wrote letters to future test takers about how to use the stories’ insights and strategies.

question4b.value: All test takers registering for the July 2019 California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in the program.

question5b.value:
In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we delivered an intervention online as a randomized-controlled trial (RCT) to applicants who sat for California’s July 2019 Bar exam. 

Beginning in March, test takers registering for the California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in. In so doing, they consented to participate in the program and permitted analysis of their Bar exam results.  At this recruitment stage, we gathered pre-intervention measures, including LSAT and their law school GPA, and matched the law school of each bar exam taker to the U.S. News & World Report Rankings.   

The program was designed as a randomized control trial (RCT).  Random assignment of Bar takers ensures the random dispersal of student traits (e.g., GPA, demographic details) between conditions. Moreover, a statistical package was applied that ensured that average prior performance scores (i.e., LSAT and law school GPA) were equal within the treatment and control condition. Every participating bar taker was then randomly assigned into either (1) the active control condition, where they learned bar exam study strategies; or (2) the treatment condition, where they received the productive mindset intervention as well as bar exam study strategies. This left the intervention treatment as the only systematic difference between the conditions.  

Those who opted-in received a link to the program in May. The program incorporated an introductory film, audio and written stories from prior test takers, and a module in which participants wrote letters to future test takers about how to use the stories’ insights and strategies. 
 
The research team will evaluate the efficacy of the intervention by matching each Bar exam taker’s intervention conditions with their performance on the bar exam. The State Bar of California has not yet, but will provide the bar exam results of each applicant who opted-in to the program.

question6b.value: Our planned sample size includes all bar exam takers who opted into the program and meet the above pre- and post-selection rules.

question7b.value:
We stopped data collection at the point at which participants were no longer able to register for the July 2019 California bar exam. 

We have no study termination rules.  If the Qualtrics program, associated videos, or program did not work properly (for example, for technical or software reasons), we would have stopped and restarted the study, however.

question8b.value:
a) U.S. Law Students in U.S. law Schools, First-Time Takers:  For purposes of this pre-registration, we are seeking to confirm the hypothesis that U.S. law students in U.S. law schools, taking the bar exam for the first time will benefit from the program.  We are excluding foreign law students, foreign law schools, repeat-test takers, and out-of-state attorneys.  

b) Failing to Complete the Program:  For purposes of this pre-registration, we are examining average treatment effects of the program.  Therefore, we are examining between-condition differences among these bar takers who completed the program.  Completing the program entailed writing responses to three prompts: stress, growth mindsets, and purpose, and a letter to a future test taker.  

c) Failing Manipulation Check:  We are not including participants who failed the manipulation check. 

d) Technical Difficulties with Program:  We are not including participants who indicated that they had technical difficulties with the program that interfered with their ability to actually take the program. 

e) Failed Distraction: We did not include participants who indicated that they were very distracted when completing the program.    

e) Not Completing the Exam:  We are not including bar applicants for whom we do not receive bar score data as they did not sit for the exam.  

f) Bar Score Outliers:  We are not including bar applicants who scored +/- 3 SD from the mean outcome on the July 2019 bar exam. 

g) Duplicate Individuals:  In the unlikely scenario that there are bar applicants who participated in both the treatment and control, we will exclude them.

question9b.value: We have no study termination rules.  If the Qualtrics program, associated videos, or program did not work properly (for example, for technical or software reasons), we would have stopped and restarted the study, however.

question7c.value: Deletion Type: Listwise deletion will be used, for example, when we do not have LSAT or LGPA.

question1a.value: [H1] Main Effect of Productive Mindset Intervention:  We expect a main effect of the productive mindset intervention on bar performance, such that U.S. law students taking the bar exam for the first time in the treatment condition will pass the bar exam at higher rates than those in the control condition.

question5a.value:
We propose that psychological friction plays an under-recognized role as a potential factor that shapes engagement and success in law school and on the bar exam. 

In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we designed and implemented a Productive Mindset intervention on the July 2018 California bar exam. The program was offered to recent U.S. law school graduates and to applicants repeating the exam. The initial results of the program were promising. On California’s July 2018 Bar exam, the program improved bar passage rates among U.S. law students who are first-time takers graduating from U.S. law schools. 

We replicated the program on California’s July 2019 Bar exam and now pre-register this direct replication prior to evaluating the results of the Productive Mindset program on the bar performance of U.S. law student who are first-time takers graduating from U.S. law schools.  

The program targets bar takers’ concerns about stress, belonging, and potential to help them interpret challenges associated with preparing for the exam in more productive ways. For instance, these bar takers may have challenges memorizing concepts and thus perform poorly on practice tests. They may construe this negative feedback as a sign that they have reached the limits of their ability. The Productive Mindset intervention encourages bar takers to reinterpret these challenges as common and surmountable, as signs of learning (not failure), and as helpful indicators of where effort and attention could be productively applied. 

[RQ1] Does a productive mindset intervention, designed to help students reappraise stress, mindsets, and purpose, improve the performance of U.S. law students taking the bar exam for the first time?

Past research suggests that the productive mindset program has an influence after controlling for participant’s prior academic performance.  US News & World Report is a close proxy for LSAT score and prior academic performance, and may be used, if we do not have sufficient LSAT score data to use LSAT as a covariate.

Covariate*: LSAT, or Law School GPA, or US News and World Report, or standardized composites of these variables. 

We may also conduct analyses on the continuous measure of bar scores.  We believe that an effect of the program on bar passage, and not bar scores themselves is possible, given the likely bulge of participants near the cutoff threshold for bar passage, whereby a small increase in score data would translate to an increased bar passage rate. 

All of the above analyses will be conducted with bar applicants who registered for the bar exam in the timely file window, and the late filing window, and then upon combining those who timely filed and late filed for the bar exam.

Analysis 1A:

Test: Logistic Regression

All of the above analyses will be conducted with bar applicants who registered for the bar exam in the timely filing window, and the late filing window, and then combining those who timely filed and late filed for the bar exam.

* We are looking at the three covariates because we seek to understand the effect of the intervention above and beyond past performance and ability. Past research suggests that the productive mindset program has an influence after controlling for participant’s prior academic performance. registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: All test takers registering for the July 2019 California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in the program.

In collaboration with the State Bar of California, we delivered an intervention online as a randomized-controlled trial (RCT) to applicants who sat for California’s July 2019 Bar exam. 

Beginning in March, test takers registering for the California Bar exam had the opportunity to opt-in. In so doing, they consented to participate in the program and permitted analysis of their Bar exam results.  At this recruitment stage, we gathered pre-intervention measures, including LSAT and their law school GPA, and matched the law school of each bar exam taker to the U.S. News & World Report Rankings.   

The program was designed as a randomized control trial (RCT).  Random assignment of Bar takers ensures the random dispersal of student traits (e.g., GPA, demographic details) between conditions. Moreover, a statistical package was applied that ensured that average prior performance scores (i.e., LSAT and law school GPA) were equal within the treatment and control condition. Every participating bar taker was then randomly assigned into either (1) the active control condition, where they learned bar exam study strategies; or (2) the treatment condition, where they received the productive mindset intervention as well as bar exam study strategies. This left the intervention treatment as the only systematic difference between the conditions.  

Those who opted-in received a link to the program in May. The program incorporated an introductory film, audio and written stories from prior test takers, and a module in which participants wrote letters to future test takers about how to use the stories’ insights and strategies. 
 
The research team will evaluate the efficacy of the intervention by matching each Bar exam taker’s intervention conditions with their performance on the bar exam. The State Bar of California has not yet, but will provide the bar exam results of each applicant who opted-in to the program.
Our planned sample size includes all bar exam takers who opted into the program and meet the above pre- and post-selection rules.

We stopped data collection at the point at which participants were no longer able to register for the July 2019 California bar exam. 

We have no study termination rules.  If the Qualtrics program, associated videos, or program did not work properly (for example, for technical or software reasons), we would have stopped and restarted the study, however.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu:
Exploratory Analyses

Analysis 1B:
Test: Linear Regression
IV: Productive Mindset (Treatment-Productive Mindset, Control-Active Study Skills) 
DV: Bar Scores
Covariate*: LSAT, or Law School GPA, or US News and World Report, or standardized composites of these variables. 

We may also conduct analyses on the continuous measure of bar scores.  We believe that an effect of the program on bar passage, and not bar scores themselves is possible, given the likely bulge of participants near the cutoff threshold for bar passage, whereby a small increase in score data would translate to an increased bar passage rate. 

All of the above analyses will be conducted with bar applicants who registered for the bar exam in the timely file window, and the late filing window, and then upon combining those who timely filed and late filed for the bar exam.

* We are looking at the three covariates because our past research suggests that the productive mindset program has an influence after controlling for participant’s prior academic performance.  US News & World Report is a close proxy for LSAT score and prior academic performance, and may be used, if we do not have sufficient LSAT score data to use LSAT as a covariate.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a) U.S. Law Students in U.S. law Schools, First-Time Takers:  For purposes of this pre-registration, we are seeking to confirm the hypothesis that U.S. law students in U.S. law schools, taking the bar exam for the first time will benefit from the program.  We are excluding foreign law students, foreign law schools, repeat-test takers, and out-of-state attorneys.  

b) Failing to Complete the Program:  For purposes of this pre-registration, we are examining average treatment effects of the program.  Therefore, we are examining between-condition differences among these bar takers who completed the program.  Completing the program entailed writing responses to three prompts: stress, growth mindsets, and purpose, and a letter to a future test taker.  

c) Failing Manipulation Check:  We are not including participants who failed the manipulation check. 

d) Technical Difficulties with Program:  We are not including participants who indicated that they had technical difficulties with the program that interfered with their ability to actually take the program. 

e) Failed Distraction: We did not include participants who indicated that they were very distracted when completing the program.    

e) Not Completing the Exam:  We are not including bar applicants for whom we do not receive bar score data as they did not sit for the exam.  

f) Bar Score Outliers:  We are not including bar applicants who scored +/- 3 SD from the mean outcome on the July 2019 bar exam. 

g) Duplicate Individuals:  In the unlikely scenario that there are bar applicants who participated in both the treatment and control, we will exclude them.

attributes.title: Number based justification->restaurant
attributes.description: This study tests the hypothesis that people are more likely to choose restaurant that can be easily justified with quantitative information (as opposed to qualitative information) when they have to justify their decision to others.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Participants’ ratings related to the perceived effort in justification will also be tested across the conditions as manipulation check.

Participants will also be asked the following questions.  The "justify" measure is a manipulation check and the "subjective" "objective" measures are potential mediators. 

How much did you feel that you had to justify your decision to others?
1=Not at all; 5=very much so

To which extend did your reasons rely on subjective feelings?
1=Not at all; 5=very much so

To which extend did your reasons rely on objective facts?
1=Not at all; 5=very much so

sample.value: The survey will have 600 psychology students from a large mid-west university as participants.

analyses.value: A chi square analysis will be used to compare participants’ choice of restaurant in each condition.

outliers.value:
Participants will also be asked the following two comprehension check questions. Only data from participants who correctly respond to both questions will be included for data analysis.

Which restaurant is described with more numbers (e.g., "good rating (4.8/5)" and "a lot of reviews (1,193)"? 
Nobie's (answer)
Emeril	
Neither

Do you recall that you were instructed to "image that you need to justify your decision to your friends about your decision" when making your decision?
Yes (answer for justification condition participants)
No (answer for non-justification condition participants)

dependent.value:
Which restaurant would you pick? 
Nobie’s 
Emeril

conditions.value:
For this study, there are 2 conditions. All participants will be given the following instruction “Now please imagine that you are arranging a dinner party for some friends. Your task is to pick from one of the two restaurants below for the dinner party.” However, half of participants will be randomly given the additional instruction “As you are doing so, image that you need to justify your decision to your friends about your decision.”

Each participant is given two descriptions of restaurants (see below; participants will also see some images that are purported to be from the restaurants)
Nobie's is a restaurant that has a very good rating (4.8/5) based on a lot of reviews (1,193). According to a recent survey from an independent local newspaper, 92% of customers say that they would recommend the restaurant to their friends and family. 

Emeril is a restaurant that has a very good review from critics. In the past, a professional food critic has wrote in a prestigious magazine the following review: "Named for his daughter and planted in the hip Warehouse District, Emeril Lagasse’s eatery leans local, offering an affordable New American lineup, from regional cheeseboards and catfish tacos to wood-fired oysters, paired with seasonal cocktails and Louisiana beers. The casual-chic digs boast a lively open kitchen and U-shaped bar – the central attractions – along with exposed-brick walls and playful murals of Gulf fish and crab."
Below are some pictures from the restaurant.

hypothesis.value: People are more likely to choose a restaurant that can be easily justified with quantitative information (as opposed to qualitative information) when they have to justify their decision to others.

attributes.title: In-group and out-group's norm ->belief in cultural appropriation
attributes.description: This study investigates whether people’s attitude toward culture appropriation is shaped by the attitudes of other in-group members (i.e., Whites in this study) or out-group members (i.e., Asians in this study)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: In-group and out-group norm->judgment on cultural appropriation

other.value:
The survey also asks two questions that will serve as manipulation check, both range from 0=Not offensive at all to 7=Extremely offensive

Base on this article, how offensive do you think Keziah's act is to White Americans?
Base on this article, how offensive do you think Keziah's act is to Chinese people?

sample.value: The survey will have 600 psychology students from a large mid-west university as participants.

analyses.value:
Two indicator variables will be created based on the condition that participants will be assigned to. One indicator represents the factor that reflects the norm for Whites (coded as 1 if most Whites are said to think it is offensive and 0 otherwise), and the other indicator represents the factor that reflects norm for Chinese people (coded as 1 if the norm for Chinese is said to think it is offensive and 0 otherwise). 
Two linear regression analyses will be conducted to predict the two dependent variables using the two indicator variables and their interactions.

outliers.value: Only participants who identify as White will be included in the analyses

dependent.value:
(responses for all items range from 1=Not at all to 7=Definitely)
DV1. (an average of the following two items)
Based on your opinion, when a White woman wears a Chinese traditional dress to her prom, 
a.	do you think it is offensive?
b.	do you think it is inappropriate?

DV2. do you think it is an act of cultural appropriation?

conditions.value: For this study, it has a total of 4 conditions. All participants will read an article about the incident that a White individual wore a Chinese-style dress to prom. The article discusses what most Whites and what most Chinese people think about the incident. The purported attitude from Whites and Chinese are manipulated in a 2 x 2 design. In particular, based on the conditions, most White people are said to believe the action of the White individual who wore a Chinese-style dress to be offensive or not offensive, and crossing with this factor, most Chinese people are said to think the action to be either offensive or not offensive.

hypothesis.value: Are people’s attitude toward culture appropriation shaped by the attitudes of other in-group members (i.e., Whites in this study) and out-group members (i.e., Chinese in this study), and if so, is one more powerful than the other?
